text:
So let's talk about
kinetic energy again.

Remember, when we have an
object moving with speed v,

we define the kinetic
energy of the object

as a scalar quantity
1/2 mv squared.
This is scalar.

And what's very
important to realize,

it is reference frame
dependent because the velocity

of the object depends on what
reference frame we're in.

One thing to keep in mind
is remember our definition

of scalar product, a dot
b is the magnitude of a,

the magnitude of v, times
the cosine of theta.

So a vector dotted
into itself is just

the magnitude of
a squared, which

we can just write as a square
because the angle is zero.
So here, we have a v squared.

So the dot product
b dot b v squared,

enables us to write
kinetic energy

as 1/2 m v dot v. And we see
our first example of the scalar

product describing
a physical quantity.

If we had a coordinate
system where

we wrote v as vx i-hat plus
vy j-hat plus vz k-hat,

and we took the dot product
of that vector with itself,

then we just know that it's
the square of the components.

And so, in a
Cartesian system, we

can now say that
the kinetic energy

is 1/2 m vx squared plus
vy squared plus vz squared

because that's the
velocity squared.

So there's a simple way
to express, abstractly,

the kinetic energy
as a dot product

and explicitly in
a coordinate system

as the sum of the squares of
the components of the velocity.
